skill.name: qutip
skill.description: Quantum mechanics simulations and analysis using QuTiP (Quantum Toolbox in Python). Use when working with quantum systems including: (1) quantum states (kets, bras, density matrices), (2) quantum operators and gates, (3) time evolution and dynamics (Schrödinger, master equations, Monte Carlo), (4) open quantum systems with dissipation, (5) quantum measurements and entanglement, (6) visualization (Bloch sphere, Wigner functions), (7) steady states and correlation functions, or (8) advanced methods (Floquet theory, HEOM, stochastic solvers). Handles both closed and open quantum systems across various domains including quantum optics, quantum computing, and condensed matter physics.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing no executable code. Pure Markdown files with QuTiP usage examples and quantum mechanics concepts. No network calls, filesystem access, or external command execution.

content.value_statement: Quantum mechanics simulations require specialized tools and expertise to model complex quantum phenomena accurately. This skill provides comprehensive QuTiP documentation for simulating closed and open quantum systems including state evolution, dissipation, measurements, and visualization for research and education.
actual_capabilities: Create and manipulate quantum states (kets, bras, density matrices) and operators
Simulate time evolution using Schrödinger, master, and Monte Carlo solvers
Model open quantum systems with dissipation, decoherence, and Lindblad dynamics
Visualize quantum states on Bloch sphere, Wigner functions, and phase space
Compute entanglement measures, fidelity, entropy, and correlation functions
Apply advanced methods including Floquet theory, HEOM, and stochastic solvers
limitations: Requires QuTiP library installation which may have complex dependencies
Limited to phenomena describable within current quantum mechanics framework
Performance scales with Hilbert space dimension; large systems require approximation
Numerical accuracy depends on solver parameters and truncation choices

use_cases.description: Model cavity QED, Jaynes-Cummings interactions, and photon dynamics with dissipation.

use_cases.title: Qubit dynamics simulation

use_cases.description: Learn quantum concepts through interactive simulations and visualizations.

prompt_templates.title: Basic quantum simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me set up a QuTiP simulation for [describe system: e.g., two-level atom, harmonic oscillator]. Include the Hamiltonian, initial state, and time evolution using [solver: sesolve/mesolve/mcsolve].

prompt_templates.title: Open quantum system
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to model an open quantum system with [describe dissipation: e.g., photon loss, dephasing]. Show me how to define collapse operators and use mesolve with Lindblad master equation.

prompt_templates.title: Entanglement analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me analyze entanglement in a [describe system: e.g., two-qubit Bell state, cavity-atom system]. Calculate [metric: concurrence, negativity, entropy] and visualize the evolution over time.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced dynamics
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to simulate a driven quantum system with [describe: e.g., periodic driving, non-Markovian bath]. Use [method: Floquet theory/HEOM/stochastic solver] and show how to interpret the results.

output_examples.input: Simulate a damped harmonic oscillator starting in a coherent state with amplitude 3
output: Collapse operator: c = √κ × destroy (κ=0.1 decay rate)
Time evolution: mesolve with 200 time points from 0 to 50
Expected behavior: Coherent state decays to vacuum with exponential envelope

best_practices: Start with small Hilbert spaces and increase dimension only until results converge
Use the simplest solver appropriate for your system (sesolve for pure states, mesolve for mixed)
Save and load quantum objects using QuTiP's native .save() and .load() methods for reproducibility
Set appropriate solver tolerances (atol, rtol) to balance accuracy and computation time
anti_patterns: Using excessively large Hilbert space dimensions without checking convergence
Forgetting to normalize states after operations that might alter normalization
Mixing units (ensure all frequencies, times, and rates use consistent units)
Using sesolve when dissipation or measurement is needed (requires mesolve or mcsolve)

faq.question: What QuTiP solver should I use for my system?
faq.answer: Use sesolve for closed systems with pure states. Use mesolve for open systems with dissipation. Use mcsolve for quantum trajectories and photon counting.

faq.question: How do I handle large Hilbert spaces efficiently?
faq.answer: Use sparse matrices (automatic in QuTiP), truncate Hilbert space based on population cutoff, and use Krylov methods for very large systems.

faq.question: Can this skill integrate with other quantum computing frameworks?
faq.answer: QuTiP can import/export from QuTiP-qip for circuit simulation. Results can interface with other tools via standard formats like QASM.

faq.question: Is my simulation data safe?
faq.answer: All simulations run locally on your machine. No data is transmitted. QuTiP saves data only to files you explicitly specify.

faq.question: Why is my simulation running slowly?
faq.answer: Check Hilbert space dimension, solver tolerances, and time step resolution. Use string-format time-dependence when possible for faster compilation.

faq.question: How does QuTiP compare to other quantum simulators?
faq.answer: QuTiP excels at continuous-variable and open quantum systems. For circuit-based quantum computing, consider QuTiP-qip or specialized SDKs.
